etymology.description: 笨 ‘clumsy’ + 手 ‘hand’ + 笨 ‘clumsy’ + 脚/腳 ‘foot’ = clumsy with hands and feet (reduplication intensifies).
etymology.interpretation: Describes someone awkward and inept in handling things and in movement; conveys lack of coordination or skill.
etymology.simplification: Only 腳 → 脚 was simplified; the right-side phonetic component was streamlined to reduce strokes while keeping the flesh radical 月, making it quicker to write.

examples.chinese: 他做家务笨手笨脚(他做家務笨手笨腳)，总是打碎杯子(總是打碎杯子)。
examples.pinyin: Tā zuò jiāwù bènshǒu bènjiǎo, zǒngshì dǎsuì bēizi.
examples.english: He’s clumsy with housework and always breaks cups.

examples.chinese: 第一次滑冰，她显得笨手笨脚(第一次滑冰，她顯得笨手笨腳)，但很快就学会了(但很快就學會了)。
examples.pinyin: Dì yī cì huábīng, tā xiǎnde bènshǒu bènjiǎo, dàn hěn kuài jiù xuéhuì le.
examples.english: At her first time ice skating, she seemed clumsy but learned quickly.

examples.chinese: 这双鞋太大(這雙鞋太大)，我走路都笨手笨脚(我走路都笨手笨腳)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè shuāng xié tài dà, wǒ zǒulù dōu bènshǒu bènjiǎo.
examples.english: These shoes are too big; I even walk awkwardly.
